6-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.title: Rate Card Gallery Walk
6-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.description: Small groups circulate through stations comparing rate tables, tape diagrams, and double-number-line models. Each stop asks for a quick annotation about which representation is most efficient and why.

outcomes: Explain how unit rate appears across representations
Justify which model is best for a given context
checkpoints: After two stations, ask each group to surface one connection they noticed.
Cold-call one station to present a sample annotation for peer feedback.

6-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.title: Unit Rate Sprint
6-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.description: Timed independent reps converting ratio tables and tape diagrams to unit rates. Students annotate which strategy they used and flag one item to discuss.

outcomes: Fluency moving between ratio, rate, and unit rate
Self-identify a sticky step to revisit
checkpoints: 3-minute burst, quick self-check with provided key
Partner compare on one flagged item

6-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.title: Ratio Reflection Log
6-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.description: Students jot two real-world ratios they noticed today, explain if each is proportional, and write one question for tomorrow. Optional home extension: capture a photo/example to share.

outcomes: Surface everyday ratio contexts
Preview misconceptions to address next lesson
checkpoints: Collect one proportional/non-proportional example
Read aloud 1–2 questions to open tomorrow

6-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.title: Equation Balance Lab
6-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.description: Teacher-led hanger and bar-model demo showing inverse operations. Students predict the next move before each reveal and justify it aloud.

outcomes: Link inverse operations to preserving equality
Practice narrating each algebraic step
checkpoints: Pause after first isolation step for a thumbs vote
Pairs write a one-step equation and swap for solution

6-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.title: Solve & Sketch Stations
6-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.description: Students rotate through stations solving one-step equations and sketching a bar model or hanger that matches. A QR hint at each station nudges them toward balance reasoning.

outcomes: Match symbolic work to a visual model
Build independence with inverse operations
checkpoints: Teacher stamps one station showing a correct sketch
Peer check using provided answer bands

6-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.title: Error Detective Exit
6-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.description: Students analyze a worked example with a common misstep (e.g., subtracting on one side). They circle the error, correct it, and write one sentence on how to avoid it at home.

outcomes: Spot and fix balance errors
Plan a quick home practice reminder
checkpoints: Share one corrected step with partner
Collect slips to sort by misconception for reteach

7-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.title: Proportional Scenarios Debate
7-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.description: Teacher presents quick scenarios (rideshare fees, recipes, map scales). Teams decide if each is proportional, defend with evidence (graph/table/equation), and respond to a counterexample.

outcomes: Identify constant of proportionality across contexts
Use multiple representations to justify reasoning
checkpoints: One-minute write: How do you know from the graph?
Swap spokespeople for final scenario to ensure full participation

7-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.title: Graph the Relationship Mini-Set
7-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.description: Independent mini-set: create a table, graph, and equation for two contexts; then label the constant of proportionality. Final item asks for a quick interpretation of slope.

outcomes: Translate between table, graph, and equation
State and interpret the constant of proportionality
checkpoints: Mid-set self-check with provided slope reminder
Teacher quick glance at one graph for feedback stamps

7-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.title: Constant of Proportionality Exit
7-mathematics-number-and-operations-rati.description: Quick exit: given a graph and a table, students write k, explain what it means, and note one real-life proportional relationship they can capture at home.

outcomes: Reinforce interpreting k from different representations
Carry the idea into a home observation
checkpoints: One volunteer shares their k meaning
Collect slips to group by misconception for next warmup

7-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.title: Inequality Card Sort Huddle
7-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.description: Students sort inequality cards (verbal, symbolic, number line) into matching sets, then justify which side is shaded and why the boundary is open/closed.

outcomes: Connect multiple representations of inequalities
Explain solution sets using boundary language
checkpoints: Teacher listens for boundary wording before whole-class share
Swap one mis-sorted pair between groups to debug

7-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.title: Two-Step Equation Ladder
7-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.description: Independent laddered practice: four two-step equations ordered by complexity. Students annotate the inverse-operations plan before solving and star the step that felt most important.

outcomes: Plan and execute inverse steps explicitly
Notice structure before operating
checkpoints: Teacher checks one annotated plan mid-way
Students pair-check last item with color-coded steps

7-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.title: When Is It True? Exit
7-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.description: Students write one inequality that matches a given context, shade it, and explain when the statement would be false. Optional home extension: capture a photo of a real-world boundary.

outcomes: Tie inequality meaning to a concrete boundary
Anticipate where a statement fails
checkpoints: Collect 2–3 examples to project next lesson
Ask one student to share their home-boundary idea

8-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.title: Method Match Challenge
8-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.description: Teams receive system cards and decide whether graphing, substitution, or elimination is most efficient. They justify the pick and solve one to prove it.

outcomes: Choose efficient methods based on structure
Defend method selection with evidence
checkpoints: Each team posts one solved system with method tagged
Teacher cold-calls a team that changed methods and why

8-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.title: Graph & Solve Studio
8-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.description: Independent studio: students graph one system and solve another by substitution. A final item asks which method they would pick for a new system and why.

outcomes: Execute multiple methods accurately
Articulate method selection criteria
checkpoints: Teacher spot-checks graph intersection
Exit poll: Which method felt fastest today?

8-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.title: System Choice Exit
8-mathematics-number-and-operations-expr.description: Students pick the best method for a new system, explain their choice, and sketch the first step. Optional home extension: find a real context that would create intersecting lines.

outcomes: Solidify method-selection heuristics
Connect systems to a real-world intersection
checkpoints: Pair-share method choice in 60 seconds
Collect ideas to seed next lesson warmup

8-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-p.title: Right-Triangle Map Walk
8-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-p.description: On grid maps, teams choose two points and estimate walking distance using right triangles. They compare estimates to map scale to discuss when the theorem applies.

outcomes: Apply the theorem to realistic coordinates
Decide when straight-line distance is appropriate
checkpoints: Teacher conferences with one pair per group to check setup
Share-out: when would path length differ from straight-line?

8-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-p.title: Pythagorean Proof Tiles
8-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-p.description: Independent practice using square tiles or digital manipulatives: build squares on legs and hypotenuse, record areas, and verify a² + b² = c² for three right triangles.

outcomes: Visualize the area relationship
Compute c given legs with accuracy
checkpoints: Teacher spot-checks one triangle build
Self-check with a non-right triangle to see failure

8-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-p.title: Distance in My World
8-mathematics-geometry-and-measurement-p.description: Exit/reflection: students pick two places from their life, sketch a right triangle on a grid, estimate distance with the theorem, and note one situation where it would not work.

outcomes: Transfer theorem to personal contexts
Recognize limits of straight-line assumptions
checkpoints: Optional: bring a photo/map to discuss next class
Collect for quick scan of misconception about right angle requirement

6-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.title: Think-Aloud: Character Shift
6-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.description: Teacher models a read-aloud of a pivotal scene, pausing to annotate the narrator’s cues and internal shifts. Students track evidence in a shared T-chart.

outcomes: Cite textual evidence for character change
Model inner voice questions while reading
checkpoints: Partner whisper: what line signaled the shift?
One-sentence evidence share before moving on

6-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.title: Evidence Flags
6-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.description: Students place sticky-note flags in their novella marking a line for character motive and a line for theme. They paraphrase the evidence and add a quick why-it-matters note.

outcomes: Select precise evidence for motive and theme
Explain why evidence is compelling
checkpoints: Teacher spot-checks two flags per student
Peer swap: trade one flag and defend the choice

6-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.title: Theme Snapshot Exit
6-english-language-arts-reading-literatu.description: Students write a two-sentence theme statement citing one line from today’s reading. Optional home extension: ask a family member which theme resonates and why.

outcomes: State a theme and anchor it to evidence
Invite a home conversation to deepen meaning
checkpoints: One volunteer shares their line aloud
Collect slips to sort for tomorrow's discussion groups

6-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.title: Mentor Text Mark-Up
6-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.description: Teacher models annotating a short argument paragraph, color-coding claim, evidence, and reasoning. Students mirror the mark-up on paper copies.

outcomes: Identify claim/evidence/reasoning structure
Notice signal words and punctuation
checkpoints: Students underline one transition and share its job
Quick cold call: where does reasoning show up?

6-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.title: Claim-Evidence Quickwrite
6-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.description: Independent 8–10 sentence quickwrite responding to a prompt. Students must bold their claim, italicize evidence, and underline the reasoning sentence.

outcomes: Produce a concise argument paragraph
Visually separate components for self-check
checkpoints: Mid-write pause to highlight reasoning
Peer swap for one sentence of feedback

6-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.title: Grammar Spot-Check Exit
6-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.description: Students repair two sentences with punctuation/usage errors in a mini argument. Optional home extension: read the fixed version to someone and ask if it sounds convincing.

outcomes: Apply grammar fixes to argument writing
Read aloud to check clarity
checkpoints: Whole-class choral read after fixing one sentence
Collect slips to target next mini-lesson

7-english-language-arts-reading-informat.title: Source Reliability Gallery
7-english-language-arts-reading-informat.description: Teacher posts short excerpts from science/tech articles with source info. Groups rank reliability, highlight signal words, and justify their ranking.

outcomes: Evaluate claims based on source credibility
Cite textual signals of bias or reliability
checkpoints: Require one quote to back each ranking
Share one 'most trustworthy' excerpt and why

7-english-language-arts-reading-informat.title: Claim vs. Evidence Sort
7-english-language-arts-reading-informat.description: Independent drag-and-drop or cut-and-sort: separate claims from supporting evidence within a short article, then rewrite one paired reasoning sentence.

outcomes: Distinguish claims from evidence
Draft reasoning that links evidence to claim
checkpoints: Teacher checks one rewrite sentence
Peer swap for a quick sense-check

7-english-language-arts-reading-informat.title: Which Source? Exit
7-english-language-arts-reading-informat.description: Students pick the most credible source from two short blurbs, cite one reason, and note where they’d verify the claim at home.

outcomes: Apply credibility checks quickly
Extend checking behavior outside class
checkpoints: One volunteer defends their pick
Ask for a home verification idea to reopen next class

7-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.title: Counterclaim Carousel
7-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.description: Teacher seeds 3–4 common counterclaims around a prompt. Groups rotate, crafting a rebuttal sentence and a grammar check (comma/semicolon) at each stop.

outcomes: Draft rebuttals that address counterclaims
Apply punctuation to complex sentences
checkpoints: Teacher highlights one rebuttal per station
Class votes on the clearest counterclaim response

7-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.title: Reasoning Ladder Draft
7-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.description: Independent drafting of a body paragraph using a scaffolded ladder: claim → evidence → reasoning → stylistic upgrade. Students highlight the reasoning sentence in another color.

outcomes: Compose a full paragraph with balanced parts
Spot gaps in reasoning before revising
checkpoints: Teacher initials once reasoning is highlighted
Optional peer micro-conference on clarity

7-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.title: Peer Mini-Conference Exit
7-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.description: Pairs swap a paragraph, read aloud one sentence, and give a sticky-note glow/grow. Home extension: read the paragraph to an adult and ask if the reasoning is convincing.

outcomes: Practice concise peer feedback
Invite a home audience to react to reasoning
checkpoints: Collect one glow/grow to inform reteach
Ask for a show of hands: who wants teacher feedback next?

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.title: Bias Hunt in Tech News
8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.description: Teacher models skimming two contrasting tech news excerpts. Groups highlight charged language, missing data, and author intent, then rate bias on a 1–4 scale.

outcomes: Evaluate argument soundness and bias indicators
Use evidence to justify bias ratings
checkpoints: Require one quote per bias flag
Whole-class compare of bias ratings

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.title: Evidence Weighing Notebook
8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.description: Independent notebook entry: gather two claims from a science/tech text, list the supporting evidence, and rate strength with a brief justification.

outcomes: Differentiate strong vs. weak evidence
Explain why evidence supports or falls short
checkpoints: Teacher initials one strength rating
Peer compare: which evidence felt weakest?

8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.title: Credibility Check Exit
8-english-language-arts-reading-informat.description: Students choose one article read today and jot: key claim, strongest evidence, and one place they’d fact-check it at home (database, expert, second source).

outcomes: Summarize claim/evidence succinctly
Plan an independent fact-check step
checkpoints: Collect slips; sort by fact-check ideas
Invite one student to share a database/website suggestion

8-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.title: Data-Driven Hook
8-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.description: Teacher displays a data snippet or graph tied to the prompt. Class co-constructs a hook and claim using the data, noting precise language and punctuation.

outcomes: Craft hooks grounded in evidence
Attend to grammar in complex introductory sentences
checkpoints: Students draft one alternative hook in pairs
Teacher spotlights a grammar upgrade live

8-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.title: Outline-to-Draft Sprint
8-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.description: Independent sprint: convert yesterday’s outline into one polished body paragraph. Students use a self-checklist for claim clarity, evidence integration, and transition variety.

outcomes: Develop a cohesive paragraph from outline
Self-assess transitions and evidence integration
checkpoints: Teacher initials once checklist is used
Optional peer read-aloud of one sentence

8-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.title: Revision Exit Checklist
8-english-language-arts-writing-and-gram.description: Students complete a 4-item checklist (claim strength, counterclaim, sentence variety, citation punctuation). Home extension: read the revised paragraph to someone and ask if the reasoning is clear.

outcomes: Revisit key revision levers
Invite an outside listener to gauge clarity
checkpoints: Teacher collects for next-day mini-lesson focus
Students star one item they want feedback on
